COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN  4

I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The ensuing project1 will contribute to the diversification of exports and the connection to 
regional markets for the Republic of Kazakhstan (Kazakhstan) and the Kyrgyz Republic. The 
ensuing project is part of the development of the Almaty-Bishkek Economic Corridor (ABEC).2 The 
project will support the modernization of wholesale markets to improve food safety, food security, 
and  increase  trade  with  key  markets.  Modern  wholesale  market  infrastructure  will  facilitate 
certification for exports, traceability systems, and most importantly, transparent market access and 
storage of fresh produce. As a result, incentives to expand agricultural production regarding quality, 
quantity, and seasonality will benefit small- and medium-sized producers in the region. 
 
2.  The ensuing project will be aligned with the following impacts: the share of agriculture in 
gross domestic product in Kazakhstan must increase five-fold by 2050,3 and raising the well-
being in the Kyrgyz Republic by improving connectivity with regional markets and developing 
the agriculture sector.4 The project will have three outputs: (i) wholesale market storage and 
logistics facilities constructed, (ii) export certification for the Eurasian Economic Union and 
other major markets established, and (iii) effective ownership and management of collection 
centers established. The outputs will result in the following outcome: share of safe and certified 
horticultural exports increased.  The project is estimated to cost $200 million ($150 million for 
Kazakhstan and $60 million for the Kyrgyz Republic). The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will 
finance $50 million for the Kyrgyz Republic from its ordinary capital resources ($25 million in 
concessional loans and $25 million in grants), and $75 million of nonsovereign financing for 
Kazakhstan from its ordinary capital resources. The governments of Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz 
Republic, $10 million each through land provision, and for the Kyrgyz Republic exemptions of 
taxes and duties for imported goods, works, and services. For Kazakhstan, $55 million is intended 
to be provided through sponsor cofinancing.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will help the governments of the Republic of 
Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic (the governments) prepare the project. Particularly, the TA 
will help with: (i) conducting the investment feasibility studies (IFSs), including all safeguards and 
financial and economic due diligence, and preparing the national feasibility study reports in form 
and substance required by the governments; (ii) undertaking the required due diligence of relevant 
city and provincial governments and their subsidiary entities for loan consideration; and (iii) loan 
processing  and  implementation  startup  for  the  ensuing  loans  for  the  Modern  Agriculture 
Wholesale Market Development Project (the Project).  
 
                                                
1  The proposed project is reflected in the Kyrgyz Republic country operations business plan for 2019–2021 for $50 
million in 2020. The Kazakh part of the project is envisaged as nonsovereign transaction and is therefore not included 
in the country operations business plan for Kazakhstan. Both countries agreed to pursue this project by protocol of 
the bilateral ABEC Subcommittee meeting, which was held on 25 September 2017 in Bishkek and reconfirmed by 
the second ABEC Subcommittee meeting on 11 June 2018 in Almaty. 
2  The ABEC comprises Almaty City, Almaty Oblast (province), and Zhambyl Oblast in Kazakhstan as well as Bishkek 
City, Chui Oblast, and Issyk-Kul Oblast in the Kyrgyz Republic. The project is not limited by the geographical scope 
of the Almaty-Bishkek Economic Corridor. 
3  Government of Kazakhstan. 2017. Strategy Kazakhstan-2050. Astana. 
4  Footnotes 2 and 3

2   
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
4.  The TA has three outputs: (i) Output 1: IFSs for ensuing project prepared. The IFSs will 
assess the worthiness and sustainability of the ensuing investment to modernize at least three 
wholesale  markets  (two  in  Kazakhstan  and  one  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic)  and  construct 
consolidation and aggregation centers in the Kyrgyz Republic. Due diligence will include all 
safeguards and financial and economic analysis; (ii) Output 2: commercial, technical and financial 
due diligence of private sector, special purpose vehicle or non-sovereign entities, including 
subsidiary entities (Kazakhstan) prepared; and (iii) Output 3: loan processing and implementation 
startup assisted to increase project readiness and expedited project implementation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
5.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,050,000, of which $1 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by TASF-other sources and $1 million will be financed on a grant basis by the Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Fund under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing 
Partnership Facility.5 The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. The governments of 
Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic will provide $50,000 equivalent of in-kind counterpart 
support in the form of office space for TA consultants, counterpart staff, data and information 
access, and facilitation of liaisons with stakeholders during the feasibility study. The government 
was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
6.  ADB will administer the TA. The Ministry of Agriculture of Kazakhstan and the Ministry of 
Agriculture, Food Industry, and Melioration of the Kyrgyz Republic will be the lead counterpart 
agencies for the TA. CWER and CWRC will act as the focal point and coordinator of consulting 
inputs and activities. The proposed TA will be implemented over 24 months, from December 2018 
to December 2020. Disbursements will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement  Handbook  (May  2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  implementation 
schedule is in Table 1.

7.  Consulting Services. The TA will require three packages of consulting services: (i) 
Package 1 – an international consulting firm to conduct the IFS (output 1) in both countries using 
the fixed budget selection (FBS) selection method, and simplified technical proposal; (ii) Package 
2 - an international consulting firm to conduct the commercial, technical and financial due 
diligence (output 2) using the FBS selection method and simplified technical proposals; and (iii) 
Package 3 - Individual consultants (international) to assist loan processing and implementation 
startup  and  coordination  of  outputs  1  and  2  (output  3).  Package  1 will  be  lump-sum  and 
performance-based contract, package 2 will be lump-sum, while package 3 will be time-based.6  
ADB procurement and policy and regulations (2017 as amended from time to time) shall apply to 
the selection of consultants. The indicative expertise and corresponding person-months are in 
Table 2.

LIST OF LINKED DOCUMENTS 
 
1.  Terms of Reference for Consultants

6                        Linked Document 1 
 
 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Output 1 – Conducting the Investment Feasibility Study 
 
1.  Scope of work. An international consulting firm will be engaged to conduct the investment 
feasibility study (IFS) using quality- and cost-based selection method with fixed budget selection 
(FBS) and simplified technical proposals. The contract with the firm will be lump-sum and 
performance-based. The firm shall assess the worthiness and sustainability of the proposed 
financing to establish three wholesale markets in Almaty and Zhambyl regions in Kazakhstan and 
in Chui region in the Kyrgyz Republic. The study shall cover, but not be limited to, the following 
aspects: market and value chain analysis, demand analysis, investment alternative analysis 
(greenfield versus brownfield options), conceptual design of each of the three wholesale market 
facilities, operation and maintenance plan, risk assessment (including business and market risks), 
economic and financial analysis, business management model and governance including public-
private partnership arrangements, financial management assessment, procurement capacity 
assessment and procurement packaging, social and gender analysis, safeguards assessment 
and planning (including preparing documents for environmental safeguards and land acquisition 
and resettlement), and the required workplan from concept phase to functional facilities. It is 
required that close consultations, discussions, and surveys of potential users/stakeholders be 
conducted to ensure the market designs are practical to the users’ purposes, and the operation 
has high likelihood of sustainability. A suggested IFS Report structure will be provided by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB). In addition, the firm shall prepare the national feasibility study 
(NFS) reports to serve as approval by the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic, and as information 
for relevant city and provincial governments and their subsidiary entities. The expected date of 
service commencement is January 2019. 
 
2.  Deliverables. The firm shall submit the following reports: (i) Inception report; (ii) Draft Final 
IFS Report; (iii) Final IFS Report after incorporating all comments and/or recommendations of 
ADB and the government; (iv) Draft Final NFS Reports including all necessary aspects covering 
technical,  institutional,  economic,  social  and  environmental  assessments,  procurement  and 
financial  management,  etc.,  required  for  the  project  approval  by  authorized  ministries  and 
agencies; and (v) Final NFS reports after approval of the NFS reports by the relevant authorities 
in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. All the reports are expected to be in English, except that 
the main text of the draft final IFS report and the project administration manual must be translated 
into Russian. The NFS reports must be in English and Russian. 
 
3.  Maximum  Budget  and  Payment  Schedule.  The  maximum  budget  for  the  IFS 
assignment is $1.56 million. The payment schedule is as follows: (i) 10% after signing the contract; 
(ii) 15% following the submission of the Inception Report; (iii) 40% following the submission of the 
draft final IFS report to the ADB and the government; (iv) 25% after incorporating comments of 
ADB and the government; and (v) 10% after ADB and the government have finished the loan 
negotiation and no more revision on the IFS report is required, and approval of the NFS reports 
by the relevant government authorities in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic followed by 
submission of approved versions of NFS to ADB.   
 
4.  Consultant’s Qualification. The minimum requirements for the firm are: (i) extensive 
and proven  experience  in  conducting  feasibility  studies  for  and/or  setting  up  holistic 
wholesale markets  for  agricultural  products  in  various  countries,  and  (ii)  at  least  15  years 
of experience for the team leader and 10 years of experience for other key staff in similar 
market value chain infrastructure development projects. It is preferred that the firm associates 
with (an)other firm(s) (domestic and/or international) which have recent and solid experience

Linked Document 1                        7 
in preparing  ADB-financed  projects  related  to  agriculture  development,  and  agriculture 
value chain infrastructure in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic.  
 
5.  Detailed Terms of Reference. The schedule of indicative consulting service inputs for 
both key specialists and non-key specialists is in Table 1. However, the firm may, at its discretion, 
propose a modified service input schedule and skills mix, if needed, to undertake the IFS. The 
outline terms of reference for each specialist are outlined hereunder. 
 
Table 1: Expected Consulting Service Inputs

6.  Team Leader/Wholesale Market Design Specialist (international: 8 person-months). 
The specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree in agriculture economics, rural development, 
business administration, project management, or a related field, with at least 15 years of relevant 
professional experience including designing and implementing wholesale market development 
projects,  particularly  physical  holistic  wholesale  markets  for  perishable  products  in  several 
countries. Knowledge of and experience in horticulture value chain development, horticulture 
export  promotion,  and  public-private  partnerships  (PPPs)  in  market  infrastructure 
financing/operation are highly preferred. The specialist will be responsible for, but not limited to, 
the following: (i) lead and coordinate the project designing process in terms of project components

8                        Linked Document 1 
 
 
and composition of the wholesale markets, conceptual/preliminary designs, and due diligence on 
various aspects as required by ADB and the government; (ii) liaise frequently and work closely 
with government ministries, agencies, sector research institutes, and other relevant stakeholders 
including the private sector firms to ensure the proposed project design is practical and has a high 
likelihood of sustainability; (iii) lead the preparation of the detailed sector assessment as a solid 
background for the proposed project design; (iv) prepare the IFS report based on ADB’s IFS 
Report Structure (to be provided by ADB) by providing his/her own inputs and consolidating 
relevant inputs provided by the team; and (v) ensure the IFS report addresses various due 
diligence aspects, such as social and gender impacts and project components that address 
gender issues, as stated in the scope of work and the IFS Report Structure, and as instructed by 
ADB and the government from time to time. 
 
7.  Deputy Team Leaders/Market Infrastructure Specialists (national: 5 person-months for 
each country). The specialists shall have at least a Bachelor’s Degree in engineering with 10 
years relevant experience, including designing and implementing similar market value chain 
infrastructure development projects in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. Past and/or ongoing 
experience in preparing/designing ADB-financed projects in the role of national (deputy) team 
leader is a must. Knowledge of and experience in cold storage development for horticulture is 
highly preferred. The specialist will be responsible for, but not limited to, the following: (i) 
coordinate with and support the team leader in carrying out his tasks related to project design, 
liaising with the government and stakeholders, report writing and compilation in accordance with 
ADB’s requirements; (ii) under the instruction of the team leader, conduct the consultations with 
horticulture  farmers,  business  firms,  and  other  stakeholders;  (iii)  sketch  out  preferred 
composition/components of the holistic wholesale markets; (iv) together with the Horticulture 
Trade Specialist and the Civil Engineer/Architect, assess and design the cold storage component 
and other associated fixtures for inclusion into the design of the holistic wholesale markets; and 
(iv) undertake other tasks related to the IFS as determined by the team leader.    
 
8.  Horticulture/Beef/Dairy Trade Specialist (international: 5 person-months; national: 3 
person-months in each country). The international specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree 
in economics, commerce/trade, finance, business administration, or a related field, with 15 years 
relevant work experience including agriculture trade (horticulture, beef, dairy) in several countries. 
The  national  specialist  shall  have  at  least  a  Bachelor’s  Degree  in  economics,  finance,  or 
commerce, with 10 years working experience with agriculture development/trade projects in 
Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. Familiarity with current agricultural trade situation and 
horticulture  value  chain  of  Kazakhstan  and  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  is  highly  preferred for  all 
specialists. The specialists are responsible for, but not limited to, the following: (i) assist the team 
leader in preparing the detailed sector assessment, that includes sex-disaggregated information, 
as  a  solid  background for  the  proposed  project  design; (ii)  analyze  the  current  source-to-
destination flows of horticultural products for both domestic consumptions and export, and 
actual/potential business and market risks to help determine/suggest the optimal locations, and 
site development options (greenfield or brownfield), estimated development/investment costs, 
and expansion plan for the three wholesale markets.  
 
9.  Architect/Structural  Engineer  (international:  2  person-months;  national:  4  person-
months in each country). The international specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree in 
civil/structural  engineering,  spatial  planning,  planning  and  real  estate  management, 
interior/exterior  design,  architecture,  or  a  related  engineering  field,  with  15  years  relevant 
experience  including  designing  modern  and  comprehensive  market  structures  in  several 
countries. The national specialist shall have at least a Bachelor’s Degree in civil engineering, 
spatial planning, planning and real estate management, interior/exterior design, architecture, or a

Linked Document 1                        9 
related engineering field, with 10 years working experience with detailed design of infrastructure 
projects  in  Kazakhstan  and  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  Both  specialists  must  be  capable  of 
handling/processing technical drawings with common graphic design software. The specialists 
are responsible for, but not limited to, the following: (i) prepare conceptual drawings of the floor 
plans of the three holistic wholesale markets with and without expansion plan based on inputs of 
relevant team members; (ii) provide narrative interpretation of the conceptual drawings and 
relevant inputs to the feasibility report for each holistic wholesale market;  and (iii) archive, in an 
organized manner, the drawings and technical parameters of the conceptual designs to serve the 
purpose of the national feasibility study reporting and the detailed design. 
 
10.  Civil Engineer (national: 3 person-months, 2 in Kazakhstan and 1 in the Kyrgyz Republic). 
The specialist shall have at least a Bachelor’s Degree in civil engineering, spatial planning, 
planning  and  real  estate  management,  interior/exterior  design,  architecture,  or  a  related 
engineering  field,  with  10  years  relevant  work  experience  including  detailed  design  of 
infrastructure projects in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. The specialist is responsible for, 
but not limited to, the following: (i) incorporate conceptual drawings of the floor plans of the three 
wholesale markets into the NFS reports; (ii) interpret the conceptual drawings and provide 
relevant inputs to the NFS reports; and (iii) ensure that the relevant NFS report sections are 
consistent with ADB’s RRP and its linked documents and present them in form and substance 
required by the Government’s prevailing regulations. 
 
11.  Wholesale  Market  Management  Specialist  (international:  3  person-months).  The 
specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree in economics, commerce/trade, finance, business 
administration, or a related field, with 15 years relevant work experience including management 
or management consulting for holistic wholesale market establishment/operation. Experience in 
PPP arrangements for market infrastructure operations is preferred. The specialist is responsible 
for, but not limited to, the following: (i) consult with various stakeholders including potential market 
management companies and lessees of the wholesale market floor space to inform the market 
design  features,  and  technical  and  operational  aspects;  (ii)  prepare  a  detailed  market 
management document elaborating, among other things, the proposed organizational/institutional 
structure for the holistic wholesale markets, practical business models including PPP contractual 
arrangements, detailed guidelines for market management based on the PPP contractual model, 
roles and responsibilities of each stakeholder involved, and cost recovery mechanisms; and (iii) 
recommend  to  the  government  any  legal  and  regulatory  aspects  that  need  to  be 
adjusted/improved to sustain the market facilities. 
 
12.  Agriculture Sector Policy Specialist (international: 2 person months, national: 4 person-
months, two in each country). The specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree in agricultural 
economics, with 10 years relevant work experience including agriculture finance, agri-trade 
(horticulture, beef and dairy) value chains, and up-to-date knowledge on sector transformation 
and reforms in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. The specialist will be responsible for the 
following:  (i)  identify  policy  gaps  or  hindrances  and  prepare  policy  recommendations  for 
incorporation in the IFS; (ii) supervise overall preparation of the NFS reports; (iii) liaise with 
government ministries, agencies, and other relevant stakeholders to ensure the reports reflect 
diverse but practical views; (iv) ensure that the NFS reports are consistent with ADB’s RRP and 
its linked documents; and (v) submit NFS reports which address various due diligence aspects 
including technical, institutional, economic, social, gender, and environmental assessments, 
procurement and financial management, etc., in form and substance required by the governments’ 
prevailing regulations.

10                        Linked Document 1 
 
 
13.  Public  Private  Partnership  Specialist  (international:  2  person-months).  The 
international PPP Specialist must have at least a Master’s Degree in Business Administration or 
Development Economics with a focus in Agriculture and at least 12 years of practical experience 
in the field of structuring PPP transactions, including experience on agriculture related projects in 
the Asia Pacific region. Past relevant work experience in Central Asia would be considered a 
significant  advantage.  The  Specialist  will  have  experience  in  the  operational  definition  of 
arrangements  for  the  public  sector  to  procure  the  private  sector  to  promote  agribusiness 
investment and efficient value addition. The expert shall have demonstrable experience in the 
development  of  transaction  models  and  their  contracting.  The  Public  Private  Partnership 
Specialist will support the overall scope of work outlined above. In particular, the consultant will 
work closely with the rest of the team and be responsible for developing suitable models for public 
private partnership along the value chains of the selected commodities. To do so, the Specialist 
will: (i) develop options for the engagements of the private sector in the prioritized agricultural 
value chains; (ii) present options and supporting SWOT assessment to public and private sector 
actors to build awareness, obtain feedback and identify priority options; (iii) prepare outline 
transaction structures for the prioritized PPP models within the market and institutional context of 
the selected value chains identified. (v) work closely with the Legal Specialist  to ensure the legal 
basis of the proposed transaction models, and to provide a legal basis for the suggested 
transaction  structures;  (vi)  work  closely  with  the  Team  Leader  to  provide  awareness  of 
engagement procedures and obtain feedback from value chain actors to ensure the suggested 
contract structures have market and lenders acceptability; and (vii) conduct awareness at all 
relevant levels of the value chain on private sector engagement arrangements and proposed 
terms of the transaction to confirm the scope of the transaction, obtain support for the risk sharing, 
and to confirm the legal basis for revenue and cost sharing options. 
 
14.  Agriculture e-commerce Specialist (international: 2 person-months, national 4 person-
months, 2 person months in each country). The specialists shall have an IT background and have 
worked with agriculture e-commerce or built e-commerce platforms preferably in Central Asia, 
Kazakhstan or the Kyrgyz Republic with 10 years relevant work experience in the IT sector. The 
specialist will be responsible for the following: (i) review and document all accessible e-commerce 
portals/apps currently in use in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic; (ii) identify e-commerce 
platform  requirements;  (iii)  work  closely  with  the  international  ICT  Specialist  to  integrate 
traceability, certification labels (RFIDs) and other veterinary control certificates, e-monitoring of 
shipments and logistics across borders; (iv) draw up detailed technical specifications for setting 
up an e-commerce platform at wholesale market level integrating various products and value 
chain actors; (v) detail out app designs and app modifications needed to suit requirements of 
multiple stakeholders and define back-end and front end descriptions; (vi) integrate all aspects of 
trade and export in agricultural products and trade  between Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic 
as well as with Eurasian Economic Union countries; (vii) identify appropriate hosting requirements 
and institutions; (viii) identify bandwidth requirements and potential providers across the two 
countries; (ix) identify data security requirements, encryption etc.; (x) detail out hardware and 
software requirements for both countries;  (xi) estimate costs and prepare equipment lists; and 
(xii) integrate ICT recommendations into IFS working closely with the international ICT Specialist, 
the Team and Deputy Team leaders.  
 
15.  Agricultural  Economist  and  Financial  Specialist  (international:  4  person-months; 
national:  3  person-months  in  Kazakhstan,  4  person  months  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic).  The 
international specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree in agricultural economics, or project 
finance, with 15 years relevant work experience including preparing economic and financial 
analyses and/or designing of agriculture value chain projects in several countries. The national 
specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree in economics, project finance, or business

Linked Document 1                        11 
administration, with 10 years relevant work experience including agriculture development/trade 
projects  in  Kazakhstan  and  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  Familiarity  with  cost  estimation  software 
programs is preferred for both specialists. They are responsible for, but not limited to, the following: 
(i) assist the team leader in preparing the detailed sector assessment as a solid background for 
the proposed project design; (ii) prepare the project cost estimates, annual revenues and cost 
estimates, and financing plan based on ADB formats; (iii) prepare the economic and financial 
analyses for the three holistic wholesale markets in compliance with ADB’s relevant guidelines; 
(iv)  prepare  financial  sustainability  analysis  (comprehensive  and  dynamic  financial  models 
including the full set of financial statements) for the potential operating entity(ies) for each 
wholesale market facility; and (v) provide inputs to and work with the Procurement Specialist in 
preparing the project procurement plan. 
 
16.  Financial Management Specialist (international: 1 person-month, national: 1 person-
months in Kazakhstan, 2 person months in the Kyrgyz Republic). The specialist shall have at least 
a Bachelor’s Degree in accounting, auditing, finance or economics with relevant experience in 
financial  management  and  governance  regimes,  and  preferably  possess  a  professional 
accountancy/finance qualification such as a Chartered Accountant, Certified Public Accountant, 
or equivalent. (S)he will be responsible for the following: (i) conduct financial management 
capacity assessments of the executing agency and other agencies related to the project financing 
in  terms  of  financial  management,  governance,  and  integrity;  and  (ii)  analyze  risks  and 
recommend mitigation measures to safeguard risk exposures of the executing agency and other 
agencies  related  to  the  project  financing;  (iii)  sustainability  assessment  of  executing  and 
implementing agencies; and (iv) design of funds flow, accounting, auditing, and financial reporting 
arrangements, including any necessity or capacity for using the  advance procedure or the 
statement of expenditure procedure. 
 
17.  Procurement Specialist (international: 3 person-months; national: 1 person-months in 
Kazakhstan, 3 person months in the Kyrgyz Republic). The international specialist shall have at 
least a Master’s Degree in economics, finance, project procurement or a relevant field, with 15 
years relevant work experience including project management and procurement in developing 
countries and has extensive experience in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. The national 
specialist shall have at least a Bachelor’s Degree in economics, finance, project procurement or 
a relevant field, with 10 years relevant work experience including project management and 
procurement in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. All specialists are required to be familiar 
with procurement guidelines and related procedures of ADB and the government. They are 
responsible for the following: (i) prepare procurement workflow and documents from the detailed 
design stage to the market commissioning stage; (ii) conduct a procurement capacity assessment 
for the executing agency in accordance with ADB’s guidelines; (iii) prepare an overview of supply 
market for the type of goods, works, and services required by the project; (iv) prepare the project 
procurement plan in collaboration with the other relevant team members including the Economist 
and Financial Specialist; and (v) assist the executing agency in undertaking advance actions in 
procurement,  namely,  (a)  preparing  the  draft  request  for  proposal  including  the  terms  of 
references for the detailed design and supervision consultant, and (b) assisting the executing 
agency in short-listing interested firms. 
 
18.  Environmental Specialist (international: 2 person-months; national: 2 person-months in 
Kazakhstan, 5 person months in the Kyrgyz Republic). The international specialist shall have at 
least a Master’s Degree in environmental management or environmental engineering, with 15 
years relevant work experience including environmental safeguards in developing countries. 
Extensive experience in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic is an advantage. The national 
specialists  shall  have  at  least  a  Bachelor’s  Degree  in  environmental  management  or

12                        Linked Document 1 
 
 
environmental engineering, with 10 years relevant work experience including as an environmental 
specialist, preferably in donor-financed projects. Both specialists are required to be familiar with 
ADB’s environmental safeguard policies and procedures. The specialists are responsible for the 
following: (i) provide data and information for finalization of environmental categorization and 
climate change screening; (ii) examine the locations for the three holistic wholesale markets and 
assess the environmental sensitivity, and climate change risks to the sites or caused by the project 
outputs;  and  (iii)  prepare  an  Initial  Environmental  Examination  Report  and  Environmental 
Management plan, and assist the implementing agencies in conducting public consultations in 
compliance with ADB’s safeguards policy. 
 
19.  Legal Specialist (international: 1 person-months; national: 2 person-months in each 
country). The international specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree in legal studies, with 
15 years relevant work experience including commercial and finance law. Extensive experience 
in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic is an advantage. The national specialists shall have at 
least a Bachelor’s Degree in legal studies, with 10 years relevant work experience including 
commercial and finance law. The legal specialists will (i) review legal matters pertaining to land 
acquisition and / or land lease contracts at all proposed WSM sites, (ii) advise, draft and review 
as required legal arrangements and documents for WSM contract management, (iii) advise, draft 
and review as required legal arrangements and documents for sub-leasing of commercial market 
spaces within the WSMs, (iv) building on the regulatory and legal review undertaken under the 
regional technical assistance 51254-001: ABEC Support,  review and advise on regulatory 
constraints which may impact on the optimal functioning of the proposed WSM, and (v) provide 
legal advisory support to the team leader as may be required.  
 
20.  The PPP Legal Specialist (national: 2 person months) must have a law related degree 
with a focus on contract and transaction law with a minimum of 5 years experience in the review 
of legal and institutional frameworks relating to private sector engagement and PPPs. The expert 
shall have a working knowledge of the current institutional framework relating to the PPP and 
similar modalities in Kazakhstan. The PPP Legal Specialist will support the overall scope of work 
outlined above. In particular, the consultant will work closely with the PPP Specialist and be 
responsible for developing suitable models for public private partnership along the value chains 
of the selected commodities. To do so, the Specialist will: (i) review the legal requirements and 
constraints for  building public  private  sector  engagement  and    agreements  including  PPP, 
management contracts, service provision agreements that share risk and returns; (ii) work closely 
with other experts in identifying the potential role for PPP arrangements and then provide a legal 
interpretation of the requirements for the public sector to initiate such arrangements, the legal 
basis and requirements for the identified arrangements, draft outline of legal contracts and 
prepare heads of terms and  supporting documentation for the development and implementation 
of such arrangements. 
 
21.  Social Safeguard/Resettlement Specialist (international: 2 person-months; national: 2 
person-months in Kazakhstan, 4 person months in the Kyrgyz Republic). The international 
specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree in social sciences, sociology, anthropology, or 
other relevant disciplines for the assignment, with 15 years relevant work experience including 
human settlement and safeguards in developing countries and has extensive experience in 
Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. The national specialists shall have at least a Bachelor’s 
Degree  in  social  sciences,  sociology,  anthropology,  or  other  relevant  disciplines  for  the 
assignment, with 10 years relevant work experience including the field of land management and 
human resettlement in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic. All specialists must be familiar with 
ADB’s safeguards policies and procedures. Following the ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(SPS, 2009), the specialists shall: (i) conduct socioeconomic surveys, social impact assessments

Linked Document 1                        13 
and census surveys; (ii) conduct stakeholders consultation and analysis; (iii) prepare analysis of 
survey results; (iv) provide inputs on social dimension and safeguard component on all project 
documents; (v) prepare and finalize the resettlement plans, in case there are land acquisition and 
resettlement impacts; and vi) prepare indigenous peoples impact categorization and assess 
impacts, and involuntary resettlement impact categorization. The specialists shall (i) prepare 
involuntary  resettlement  categorization  checklist;  (ii)  prepare  due  diligence  report  on 
land acquisition  and  resettlement  in  case  there  are  no  resettlement  impacts;  (iii)  prepare 
land acquisition and resettlement plans, and monitoring, disclosure and grievance procedures; 
(iv) coordinate with project team to ensure that mitigation measures are integrated into the 
project design features; (v) ensure that resettlement related information are well considered 
and included in the program communication plan; (vi) assess the capacity of the executing 
agency to screen impacts, prepare and implement resettlement plans; and (vii) recommend 
appropriate capacity development activities to develop or enhance safeguards knowledge and 
skills of executing agency. 
 
22.  Social Development and Gender Specialist (national: 2 person-months in Kazakhstan, 
4 person months in the Kyrgyz Republic). The specialist shall have at least a Bachelor’s Degree 
in social sciences, sociology, anthropology, or other relevant disciplines for the assignment. (S)he 
shall have at least 10 years relevant experience in social development and/or gender and 
development. Familiarity with ADB policies on social safeguards, gender and development, and 
core labor standards is required. Working experience in agriculture and natural resource sector 
in Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic is highly preferred. The specialist is responsible for the 
following: (i) conduct a social development and gender assessment, highlighting: men and 
women's roles and tasks; their access to resources, technologies and services, gender-based 
inequalities; assessment on core labor standards, particularly on child labor and equal pay for 
equal work; constraints faced by men and women involved in the horticulture value chain, and 
recommendations to address these issues through the project’s outputs or interventions; (ii) carry 
out field surveys and/or focus group discussions to inform the social development and gender 
assessment; (iii) collect and ensure the collection of sex-disaggregated data; and (iv) prepare the 
project-specific gender action plan, and the summary poverty reduction and social strategy based 
on ADB’s template, and provide inputs into other IFS documents in compliance with ADB’s social 
safeguards and gender mainstreaming policies. 
 
B.  Output 2: Due Diligence of the Sponsor/s (e.g. city and provincial governments and 
their subsidiary entities, other public sector entities or private entities as required). 
 
23.  Proposed Facility: Long term, senior secured, bilateral loan to special purpose vehicles 
(the Borrowers) owned by the Sponsor for up to a total of US$75 million based on non-sovereign 
market standard terms and conditions. 
 
24.  Scope of work. An international consulting firm will be engaged to conduct a commercial 
and financial due diligence of the Sponsor and the proposed investment using fixed budget 
selection (FBS) and simplified technical proposals. The contract with the firm will be lump-sum. 
The key objective of the due diligence is to assess the Sponsor’s ability to serve its debt 
obligations over the life of the proposed ADB loan and the Sponsor’s ability to honor the corporate 
guarantee given to back ADB’s loan to the Borrower. Accordingly, the financial models will be a 
critical of the study.  
 
25.  The services to be provided by the consultant firm towards due diligence will be divided 
into the following components:

14                        Linked Document 1 
 
 
(i)  Commercial analysis for each Sponsor and Borrower; 
(ii)  Technical analysis for each Sponsor and Borrower;  
(iii)  Review of financials and preparation of a financial model (comprehensive and dynamic 
financial model including the full set of financial statements) for each Sponsor and 
Borrower (on a standalone as well as consolidated basis); and 
(iv)  Technical analysis of the project feasibility study, including, but not limited to, market 
and value chain analysis; demand analysis; investment alternative analysis (greenfield 
versus brownfield options); conceptual design of both wholesale market facilities; 
economic and financial analysis including verification of project cost, financing plan, 
returns  analysis;  and  business  management  model  including  for  public-private 
partnership arrangement. 
 
26.  The extent of the commercial, technical and financial analysis for group entities other than 
the Borrower will depend on the final structure of the facility including extent of guarantees from 
other operating companies, loan covenants, etc.  
 
27.  Sponsor analytical. The due diligence will entail a full analysis including, but not limited 
to, the following aspects of the borrower and/or borrower group. 
 
(i)  Structure and ownership including identification of the corporate structure, ultimate 
beneficial owners, shareholding, etc. 
(ii)  Description of the corporate governance standards based on detailed requirements by 
ADB 
(iii)  Description and analysis of the compliance and audit policies 
(iv)  Description and analysis of the sector's business overview and market environment 
(v)  Detailed  descriptions  of  the  entity's  business  plans,  strategy,  including  financial 
projections, 
(vi)  SWOT analysis, key risks and mitigants, etc.  
(vii)  Description and analysis of the risk management policies 
(viii)  Detailed  analysis  of  historical  financial  performance  including  peer  review  and 
commentary on the financial standing 
 
28.      Commercial Analysis  
(i)  Industry Analysis 
a.  Market Analysis – size of the industry, historical and future growth trends, 
factors driving growth and volatility, regulatory regimes. 
b.  Price analysis – pricing dynamics for key products, breakdown of margins and 
assessing key stakeholders along the value chain and their bargaining power 
to fix prices. 
c.  Competitive Landscape – other private sector players, both women and men 
in similar businesses with their market shares, positioning, target customers 
and markets, pricing strategy. Identification of barriers to entry. 
(ii)  Company’s  Positioning  –  competitive  strengths  and  weaknesses  based  on 
business model and end to end value chain analysis, ability to adapt to customer 
requirements,  assessment  of  company’s  strengths  and  weaknesses  on 
management,  sex-disaggregated  human  resources,  systems,  and  corporate 
governance,  and  other  organizational  dimensions.  Assess  company’s 
management’s managerial and entrepreneurial skills and ability to modify plans as 
markets, products, infrastructure, and competitors evolve.  
(iii)  Supply Chain Analysis – analyze the different procurement arrangements and 
comment on how each arrangement mitigates volume, price, and quality risks in

Linked Document 1                        15 
the  long-term;  discuss  commercial  arrangements  with  external  suppliers  of 
services  along  the  value  chain  such  as  transport,  storage  and  warehousing 
services, etc.; analyze the food safety and food quality risks (e.g. risks of food 
contamination) along the value chain. 
(iv)  Sales, Marketing and Distribution – Analyze the sales, marketing and distribution 
infrastructure, long term contracts, etc.  
 
29.    Technical Analysis 
(i)  Existing Facilities – review quality of building and equipment, processing plants; 
comment  on  production  processes,  capacity  utilization,  quality  processes, 
maintenance cycle, management, and working relationships in these facilities. 
(ii)  Planned Facilities – review the proposed project sites and comment on suitability 
for  construction,  water  and  power  connections,  access  to  transportation, 
availability of staff, proximity of business partners; and review the proposed design 
and equipment. Comment on the suitability of proposed method of construction 
and proposed equipment; and validate project cost; confirm suitability of proposed 
arrangements  for  operation  and  maintenance  including,  but  not  limited  to, 
availability  of  management  and  operational  expertise,  quality  systems, 
procurement  and  distribution  systems,  food  safety  and  quality  standards, 
emergency and contingency plans. 
 
30.    Financial Analysis 
(i)  Analyze past financials including revenue growth by business line, EBITDA margin 
by business line, level of working capital (inventories, receivables, and advances) 
by business line, and comment on any abnormality in comparison to industry 
benchmark. 
(ii)  Prepare detailed investment program and confirm that the amounts and timing of 
investment are appropriate given market demand, and the Company’s competitive 
positioning, and its current capacity utilization of the existing production lines. 
Suggest a revised, conservative investment plan as required. 
(iii)  Based on the above tasks, the Consultant will prepare the financial projections, 
including a breakdown by business line, etc. The Consultant will recommend 
revised conservative base case financial projections and provide ADB with suitable 
revised assumptions. The Consultant will also suggest sensitivity scenarios to be 
run on the financial projections. 
 
31.     Deliverables. The firm shall submit the draft commercial and financial due diligence report 
4 months after contract signing, and the final report 6 months after contract signing. The payment 
schedule is as follows: (i) 25% after contract signing, (ii) 60% following the submission of the draft 
commercial and financial due diligence report, and (iii) 15% following the submission of the final 
report to the ADB.  All reports are to be in English. 
 
32.    Consultant’s Qualification. The minimum requirements for the firm are: (i) extensive and 
proven experience in conducting commercial and financial due diligence analysis, and (ii) the 
completion of at least 5 commercial and financial due diligence and analytical due diligence 
assignments in countries of the former Soviet Union.  The team leader should have at least 15 
years of experience and other key staff in team at least 10 years of experience.

16                        Linked Document 1 
 
 
C.   Output 3 - Assisting Loan Processing and Implementation Startup 
 
33.    Project Design and Startup Specialists (international: 7 person-months). The specialists 
shall have at least a master’s degree in agricultural economics, or project finance, with 15 years 
working experience in designing and implementing wholesale market modernization projects 
including in developing countries. Familiarity with ADB reporting, due diligence, procurement, and 
disbursement guidelines and practices is an advantage. The specialist will be engaged on an 
intermittent basis prior to the loan fact-finding mission to undertake the following: (i) address 
critical technical gaps in the horticulture sector and market assessments, financial, business and 
market risks, financial and economic evaluation, among other aspects of due diligence during the 
loan processing stage; (ii) assist with the NFS reports preparation as technical oversight; and (iii) 
provide implementation startup support. These activities to be carried out in Kazakhstan and the 
Kyrgyz Republic are to ensure that (i) proper ADB’s Board documents are prepared and technical 
revisions are made during the loan processing; (ii) the NFS report is harmonized and technically 
consistent with the RRP and its linked documents; and (iii) disbursement is expedited.

Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.
